value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">8</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">my time"</quote> wrote <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-aclif" key="Clifford, Ann">Lady Anne Clifford</rs> <quote source="#" rend="inline">playing at Clecko</quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>and hearing <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mnev" key="Neville, Moll">Moll Neville</rs> read the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-arca" key="Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia">Arcadia</rs>... <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-unkn">Rivers</rs> used to</l>
            <l>
              <choice>
                <sic>r ad</sic>
                <corr>read</corr>
              </choice> to me in <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mmon" key="Montaigne, Michel de">Montaignes</rs> <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-essa" key="Essais (Michel de Montaigne)">essays</rs> and Moll Neville in the</l>
            <l><rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Faery Queen</rs>."</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The book must find its way into the hall, into the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great room where 
            <choice>
              <sic>novles</sic>
              <corr>nobles</corr>
            </choice> and 
            <choice>
              <sic>genrty</sic>
              <corr>gentry</corr>
            </choice> have 
            <choice>
              <sic>liesure</sic>
              <corr>leisure</corr>
            </choice> to read</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">after the 
            <choice>
              <sic>busniess</sic>
              <corr>business</corr>
            </choice> and the sport of the day is over.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">And with the printed book, the writer at last comes into</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">existence--the writer wxxxxx who, 
            <choice>
              <sic>unl e</sic>
              <corr>unlike</corr>
            </choice> the 
            <choice>
              <sic>mistrel</sic>
              <corr>minstrel</corr>
            </choice>,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">has a name; whose words are printed. He is in being after</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">1477 but he 
            <choice>
              <sic>stillundiffrentiated</sic>
              <corr>is still undifferentiated</corr>
            </choice>, limited. For when familiar</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">letters are written in Biblical prose, only in emergency</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">there must be a barrier between the sayable and the unsayable</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a limit to what can be put into words. The artist-- who</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">stands outside, by some impulse desiring to observe and to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">state rather than to take part, is not wholly writer,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wholly musician or wholly painter. It seems possible that the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great English art may not 
            <choice>
              <sic>b </sic>
              <corr>be</corr>
            </choice> the art of letters. 
            <choice>
              <sic>   ry</sic>
              <corr>Every</corr>
            </choice> word</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is read aloud; every word is given weight and edge by the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">speaking voice. And then the lute, the virginals 
            <choice>
              <sic>the</sic>
              <corr>they</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">gave lilt, 
            <choice>
              <sic>rhymn</sic>
              <corr>rhythm</corr>
            </choice> and melody ot the written word.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">When in 1666 the london was burning and the citizens</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">were loading their goods into boats <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-spep" key="Pepys, Samuel">Pepys</rs> noted that <quote source="#" rend="inline">"hardly</quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>one lighter or boat in 
              <choice>
                <sic>threee</sic>
                <corr>three</corr>
              </choice> that had the goods of a</l>
              <l>house in it, but there was a pair of virginals in it."</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Music, and the speaking voice lay beneath the words;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the words themselves were elastic. No grammar bound them</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">tightly together. They could be danced to and sung to. 
            <choice>
              <sic>Neverh</sic>
              <corr>Nevertheless</corr>
            </choice></l>
